Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of crawling male baby, probably Harpocrates. He leans forward with both his hands on the floor. Mould-made from a two-piece mould and hollow. Traces of a white coating. Organic red-brown Nile silt with abundant mica inclusions. Back and top half of figure missing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of Ptolemaic Harpocrates figures are known from Naukratis, mostly dating from the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC. This is likely an early Ptolemaic piece as it seems to follow 5th century BC Classical Greek period temple boy figures (GR 1863,0728.283) also known from Naukratis (Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1886.493).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.020) (Phase 3)
